Macron: Nato je možgansko mrtev
07 Nov 2019, 14:14 by STA

Nato je možgansko mrtev, je v pogovoru za The Economist dejal francoski predsednik Emmanuel Macron in opozoril, da Evropa stoji na robu prepada. Evropa mora začeti strateško razmišljati o sebi kot o geopolitični sili, saj v nasprotnem primeru "ne bomo več obvladovali svoje usode", je dejal.



Francoski predsednik Emmanuel Macron Foto: STA

PARIZ > Francoski predsednik je evropske države opozoril, da se ne morejo več zanašati na ZDA pri obrambi zaveznic Nata. "Trenutno doživljamo možgansko smrt Nata," je dejal.
Po njegovi oceni ZDA obračajo hrbet svojim zaveznicam, v zvezi s tem pa je omenil odločitev Washingtona o umiku ameriških enot iz severovzhodne Sirije. "Med ZDA in njenimi zaveznicami v Natu ni nobene koordinacije pri sprejemanju strateških odločitev. Nobene," je opozoril Macron.
"Treba bi bilo ponovno oceniti resničnost tega, kaj Nato je v luči zavez ZDA," je poudaril Macron in izrazil prepričanje, da se lahko Evropa brani sama, če se "pospeši razvoj evropske obrambe".
Francoski predsednik je izrazil razočaranje, ker so ZDA z umikom svojih enot s severa Sirije dejansko dovolile Turčiji, da izvede operacijo v Siriji. "Nato kot sistem ne regulira svojih članic," je dejal. Kot je še dodal, "ni v našem interesu" izključiti Turčijo iz Nata, vendar pa bi bilo treba "morda ponovno razmisliti, kaj Nato je".
Macronove izjave, v katerih postavlja pod vprašaj učinkovitost Nata, bi utegnile precej pretresti zavezništvo pred decembrskim vrhom zavezništva v Veliki Britaniji.

Macron: Then he's brain dead
07 Nov 2019, 14:14 by STA

He is then brain dead, French President Emmanuel Macron said in an interview with The Economist, noting that Europe is on the brink of a precipice. Europe must begin to think of itself strategically as a geopolitical force, otherwise "we will no longer control our own destiny," he said.



French President Emmanuel Macron Photo: STA

PARIS> The French president has warned European countries that they can no longer rely on the US to defend NATO allies. "We are currently experiencing the brain death of NATO," he said.
In his estimation, the US is turning its back on its allies, in which he referred to Washington's decision to withdraw US troops from northeast Syria. "There is no coordination between the US and its NATO allies in strategic decision making. None," Macron noted.
"The reality of what NATO is in the light of the US commitments should be reassessed," Macron stressed, believing that Europe could defend itself if it "accelerated the development of European defense."
The French president expressed disappointment that by withdrawing his troops from northern Syria, the US actually allowed Turkey to conduct an operation in Syria. "NATO does not regulate its members as a system," he said. He added that "it is not in our interest" to exclude Turkey from NATO, but that "it might be necessary to reconsider what NATO is".
Macron's statements calling into question NATO's effectiveness could greatly shake the Alliance ahead of the Alliance's December summit in Britain.
